Maternal risks

Preeclampsia / gestational hypertension
Pathway: Placental hormones → systemic insulin resistance → endothelial dysfunction + inflammation → hypertension and proteinuria.

Cesarean delivery & operative complications
Pathway: Fetal macrosomia → obstructed labor / shoulder dystocia risk → surgical delivery.

Progression to type 2 diabetes (T2DM)
Pathway: Pregnancy unmasks pre-existing β-cell insufficiency; postpartum insulin resistance persists → overt diabetes.

Future cardiometabolic disease
Pathway: Shared mechanisms of insulin resistance, chronic inflammation, and dyslipidemia → long-term vascular risk.

Polyhydramnios
Pathway: Fetal hyperglycemia → osmotic diuresis → increased amniotic fluid volume.

Neonatal / fetal risks

Macrosomia (excess fetal growth)
Pathway (Pedersen hypothesis): Maternal hyperglycemia → placental glucose transfer → fetal hyperinsulinemia → increased fat and shoulder/trunk growth.

Shoulder dystocia & birth trauma
Pathway: Disproportionate fetal growth → mechanical delivery complications.

Neonatal hypoglycemia
Pathway: Chronic fetal hyperinsulinemia persists after birth → rapid postnatal glucose drop.

Respiratory distress syndrome (even at term)
Pathway: Insulin antagonizes cortisol → delayed surfactant synthesis → impaired lung maturation.

Preterm birth
Pathway: Polyhydramnios, preeclampsia, or indicated early delivery for maternal/fetal risk.

Metabolic programming (long-term risk)
Pathway: In-utero hyperglycemia → epigenetic and metabolic imprinting → increased lifetime risk of obesity and T2DM.

Testing approaches for GDM
1️⃣ One-step approach (75-g OGTT)

Common outside the U.S. (WHO / IADPSG-based)

Performed at 24–28 weeks’ gestation

Fasting, then glucose measured at 1 hour and 2 hours

Diagnosis is made if any one value is abnormal

Thresholds (mg/dL | mmol/L):

Fasting ≥ 92 mg/dL (≥5.1)

1 hour ≥ 180 mg/dL (≥10.0)

2 hours ≥ 153 mg/dL (≥8.5)

Logic: Based on continuous risk (HAPO data) — thresholds correspond to increased odds of adverse pregnancy outcomes.

2️⃣ Two-step approach (U.S.-centric)

Most commonly used in the U.S.

Step 1 — Screening test

50-g glucose challenge test (non-fasting)

Plasma glucose at 1 hour

Positive screen if ≥ 130–140 mg/dL (7.2–7.8 mmol/L)

Step 2 — Diagnostic test

100-g OGTT (fasting)

Glucose measured at fasting, 1h, 2h, 3h

Diagnosis requires ≥2 abnormal values

Common thresholds (Carpenter–Coustan):

Fasting ≥ 95 mg/dL (≥5.3)

1 hour ≥ 180 mg/dL (≥10.0)

2 hours ≥ 155 mg/dL (≥8.6)

3 hours ≥ 140 mg/dL (≥7.8)

(Older National Diabetes Data Group criteria use higher cutoffs.)

Special situations

Early pregnancy testing (first trimester) may be done in high-risk women

Overt diabetes (not GDM) is diagnosed if:

Fasting glucose ≥126 mg/dL

Random glucose ≥200 mg/dL with symptoms

HbA1c ≥6.5%
